Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil.

Catherine, are you tall enough?
speaker: Neil

text: Tall enough for what?
Tall enough to be happy with your height.
speaker: Neil

text: Oh well, yes, I'm alright with my height.
I can't do a thing about it anyway.
So how about you?
Well, the same, really

text: I wouldn't mind being a slightly taller, I suppose,
which is appropriate as today's topic is about heightism.
Hightism. Now you may not have heard of heightism before,
but it's like other isms, like racism, sexism, ageism,
and other isms that highlight a particular kind of discrimination
or unequal treatment that people experience.
But before we find out more about this topic,
speaker: Neil

text: our quiz question for today.
The tallest person ever proven to live was Robert Wodlow from the USA,
but how tall was he?
Was he A, 2 metres 71 centimetres?
B, 2 metres 72?
Or C, 2 metres 73?
What do you think, Catherine?
speaker: Neil

text: Wow, that's really, really tall!
speaker: Catherine

text: I'm going to guess 2 metres 71.
Well, listen out for the answer at the end of the programme.
Tanya S. Osensky is an attorney and author of the book Short Changed
about her own experiences of heightism.
Clever title.
speaker: short-changeshort-changed

text: To short change someone is to not give them what they're entitled to,
what they deserve.
And originally this phrase comes from paying for something and not getting the right money back.
So if I buy something for £6 and I pay with a £10 note and the shopkeeper only gives me
£3 back, I've been short-changed.
It means I've been cheated.
And in the context of facing discrimination because you're not tall,
short-changed is a really good pun.
Tanya spoke about her book on the BBC Radio programme thinking allowed.
She talks first about our general feelings about height.
What does she say people never wish for?
Everybody that I've spoken to who is tall relishes their height.
speaker: relishes embellish

text: I have not met anybody who said they would wish they were shorter.
speaker: Neil

text: And people generally tend to even embellish what their height is when you ask them what it is.
So what is it she says no one wishes for?
Well, she says no one wishes they were shorter!
speaker: Catherine

text: And that's right, she said that tall people relish their height.
This means they enjoy being tall, they get great satisfaction from it.
And another point she makes is that many people embellish their height if asked.
This means they say they're taller than they actually are.
Now to embellish a fact means to exaggerate it to make it seem bigger,
faster, better and so on.
Here is Tanya Esersinski again.
Everybody that I've spoken to who is tall relishes their height.
I have not met anybody who said they would wish they were shorter.
And people generally tend to even embellish what their height is when they when you ask them what it is.
She goes on to explain how some research has shown that shorter people are less likely to get jobs,

text: less likely to get promoted and less likely to earn as much as taller people.
What is the financial difference she mentions?
She talks about the premium per inch.
An inch is about 2.5 centimeters and the premium is a word which means the extra benefit the extra
advantage.

text: Here's Tanya Esersinski again.
One set of data showed that the premium for height is over $2,000 per inch for men
and $1,000 per inch for women.
And over time that disparity grows significantly.
So it ends up being a huge chunk of someone's paycheck over their career.
She says that taller men earn $2000 an inch.
speaker: Catherine

text: For women it's a bit less but still significant at $1,000 an inch.
And this disparity or difference between the salaries of taller and shorter people is an example
speaker: disparity heightism

text: of heightism.
shorter people she says are getting fewer jobs and fewer benefits because they're short.
Well one person who certainly wasn't short with the subject of today's quiz question,
the tallest person who has lived Robert Wodlow.

Well you were almost there.

Now Catherine much as I relish being in the studio with you we must wrap up the program now
with a review of today's vocabulary.
Well relish was one of those words.
speaker: relish relish

text: If you relish something you really enjoy it.
So thanks for that Neil.
You're welcome.
This program was about a kind of discrimination.
This means the unfair or unequal treatment of people because of, for example,
their race, religion, color, age or indeed height.
And discrimination because of someone's height is called heightism.
Something which many of us do is embellish our height.
We say we are taller than we actually are.
A premium is an extra benefit or advantage that can be gained in this case by being taller.
And finally we had disparity, another word for difference.
There's a disparity between salaries of told people and their shorter colleagues.
